abstract.p: Footlights column; PS 1 art gallery offers events recalling drive-in movie era; musical American Story recalls 1913 miners strike in Colorado; National Flute Assn convention to honor memory of Jean-Pierre Rampal; photos; Museum of the City of New York to hold East Harlem Weekend (S)

block.p: Sand, sea, stars and cinema. Could it get any better? B-movie buffs can throw down their beach blankets and dig in their toes when ''Dive-In Movies: Flix From the Great B-yond'' recreates the legend of the drive-in movie at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue in Long Island City, Queens. The two-night series offers short experimental films before venturing into alien territory with a 3-D version of ''The Creature From the Black Lagoon'' on Thursday and ''Cobra Woman'' on Aug. 24. Both programs run from 9 p.m. to midnight and take place on ''Dunescape,'' an urban beach by the architecture group Shop, resplendent with pools, misters and a boardwalk. Information: (718) 784-2084.

In September 1913 some 11,000 miners in southern Colorado went on strike to protest low wages, dangerous conditions and the domination of their lives in towns controlled by the mining companies. On April 20, 1914, in an attempt to persuade strikers at the Ludlow Mine Field to return to work, company guards, engaged by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and other mine operators, and sworn into the state militia for the occasion, attacked a union tent camp with machine guns, then set it afire. Five men, 2 women and 12 children died. This event is retold in Laurel Vartabedian and Bill Evans's musical ''American Story,'' which begins its nine-performance run tonight at the Pantheon Theater, 303 West 42nd Street, Clinton, as part of the Midtown International Theater Festival. Information: (212) 279-4200.

More than 3,000 flutists will honor the memory of one of their own, Jean-Pierre Rampal, when they converge on Columbus, Ohio, on Thursday for the annual National Flute Association convention. Rampal, who died on May 20, is the subject of ''Odyssey: A Flutist's Journey,'' including flutists of genres classical (Carol Wincenc, Walfrid Kujala), jazz (Holly Hofmann, Cesar Peredo), Celtic (Joannie Madden) and Latin (Marco Granados).

There's no place like home. There's no place like home. That's the mantra that the Museum of the City of New York has subscribed to for the last five years by paying homage to its own neighborhood. ''Celebrate East Harlem Weekend,'' on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, features a behind-the-scenes tour of notable sites, a documentary about Latin music in the United States, and a book party for Judith Freidenberg's ''Growing Old in el Barrio,'' which grew from the museum's 1992 exhibition ''Growing Old in Spanish Harlem,'' to be shown in video form. Information: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.
